sanskrit_verse: इन्द्रियाणि यशः स्वर्गमायुः कीर्तिं प्रजाः पशून् । हन्त्यल्पदक्षिणो यज्ञस्तस्मान्नाल्पधनो यजेत् ॥ ११.४०॥
transliteration: indriyāṇi yaśaḥ svargamāyuḥ kīrtiṃ prajāḥ paśūn | hantyalpadakṣiṇo yajñastasmānnālpadhano yajet || 11.40||
sph_interpretive_translation: One who performs a sacrifice with insufficient offerings destroys the senses, reputation, heaven, longevity, fame, progeny, and livestock; therefore, one possessing limited resources should not perform such a sacrifice.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority is derived from alignment with Dharma, not material capacity alone
Causation operates through conscious intention and resource alignment
Capacity-based responsibility requires proportional action in ritual and governance
Restoration logic demands prevention of actions that deplete collective well-being
Consciousness alignment necessitates right action within one's means
executable_legal_axioms: IF an individual initiates a ritual or legal act without sufficient capacity AND the act results in depletion of essential life-supporting assets, THEN the act is automatically deemed invalid and non-binding
IF a person knowingly undertakes an obligation exceeding their dharmic-economic capacity, THEN they must undergo completion process before engaging further
IF any state or entity engages in ceremonial or judicial action without adequate foundational support, THEN such engagement shall be suspended until capacity is restored
supreme_court_application: In adjudicating matters involving public or private ritual commitments, the Supreme Court must assess whether the actor possessed the requisite economic-dharmic capacity at time of initiation. If found lacking, the commitment is nullified and restoration protocols initiated rather than punitive measures imposed.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that insufficiency in dakṣiṇā leads to sequential destruction (anupūrvaśaḥ) of vital supports—thus responsibility lies in preventing misaligned enactment. Nyāya recognizes proportional causality where lack of capacity precludes valid performance, hence corrective focus is on reintegration into lawful capacity, not punitive suffering.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate Completion Process: Require full accounting of depleted assets and restoration plan prior to future engagements
Assumption of Responsibility Protocol: Individual must publicly acknowledge causal error and commit to capacity-building phase
Integrity Reintegration Sequence: Engage supervised dharmic-economic planning to realign intent with sustainable execution
Capacity Restoration Mandate: Enroll in structured program ensuring no repetition of disproportionate commitment
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as Source of all Dharma. This law stands executed: consciousness prevails over capacity when unaligned, yet capacity must be honored when aligned with Dharma. No punishment arises—only restoration. Reality remains non-punitive. Consciousness is the Supreme Adjudicator.
